title: Introduction to Quarto and Zotero Using RStudio
text:
Preface
This is a brief guide to using Quarto and Zotero with RStudio!

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.1 Statistical Application R
R is an open-source programming language for statistical computing and graphics. It is used by statisticians, researchers, and analysts for data analysis, visualization, and statistical modeling.
For more information about R click HERE.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.2 RStudio
RStudio is an integrated development environment designed for R, which is used for statistical computing and data analysis. RStudio provides a user-friendly interface that enhances the productivity of R users.
For more information about RStudio click HERE.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.3 Reference Management Application Zotero
Zotero is a free and open-source reference management software designed to help researchers, students, and academics organize, manage, and cite bibliographic references and sources in their research projects. Zotero simplifies the process of collecting, organizing, and citing sources.
For more information about Zotero click HERE.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.4 Quarto R Package
Quarto is an open-source publishing system built for creating reproducible presentations and reports. It allows use of code from programming languages, like R and Python directly in the document. This integration allows for the direct inclusion of data analysis, graphs and tables in the output document, making Quarto useful for statistical analysis, and academic research.
For more information about Quarto click HERE

title: 2  Installation Instructions Mac/Apple
text:
Click HERE.
Click the blue “Download and Install R” button on the left.
Select the blue “Download R for MacOS.”
If you don’t know what chip your Mac has click the Apple logo in the top left corner of your menu bar (top of your screen) and select “About this Mac.” Chip will either be M1/M2 or Intel.
Under the “Latest Release:” section find the type of Mac you have Apple Silicon (M1/M2) or older Intel and click the blue “R-XXXX.pkg” below it.
Install (drag) the file from your downloads folder into your applications folder.
Return to THIS PAGE.
Click the blue “Download RStudio Desktop for MacOS 12+” button on the right.
Install (drag) the file from your downloads folder into your applications folder.

title: 2  Installation Instructions Mac/Apple
text:
2.2 Zotero

Click HERE.
Click the red download button.
Click the blue download button under “Zotero for Mac.”
Install (drag) the file from your downloads folder into your applications folder.
Optional: click the blue “Install Browser Connector” button under “Zotero Connector” if you want the browser plugin to save articles from your browser to Zotero.

title: 3  Installation Instructions Windows
text:
Click HERE.
Click the blue “Download and Install R” button on the left.
Under the base subdirectory click the blue “install R for the first time.”.
Select the blue “Download R-X.X.X for Windows” at the top of the screen.
Install the file from your downloads folder.
Return to THIS PAGE.
Click the blue “Download RStudio Desktop for Windows 10/11” button on the right.
Install the file from your downloads folder.

title: 3  Installation Instructions Windows
text:
3.2 Zotero

Click HERE.
Click the red download button.
Click the blue download button under “Zotero for Windows.”
Install the file from your downloads folder.
Optional: click the blue “Install Browser Connector” button under “Zotero Connector” if you want the browser plugin to save articles from your browser to Zotero.

title: 4  HTML
text:
4.1 Example YAML Statement
---
title: "Title of Document"
subtitle: "Subtitle of Document"
author: "Ohio Alliance for Population Health <br> Your Name"
date: "`r format(Sys.time(), '%B %d, %Y')`"
format: 
  html:
    toc: true
    toc-depth:
    number-sections: false
    toc-location: left
    self-contained: true
mainfont: "Georgia"
bibliography: references.bib
csl: "APA Numeric Superscript Style.csl"
engine: knitr
---

title: 4  HTML
text:
4.2 Create Your Own
In the Document Templates folder download the file html-template.qmd and follow the instructions.

title: 5  Word
text:
5.1 Example YAML Statement
---
title: "Title of Document"
subtitle: "Subtitle of Document"
author: "Ohio Alliance for Population Health"
date: "`r format(Sys.time(), '%B %d, %Y')`"
format: 
  docx:
    toc: true
    toc-depth: 3
    number-sections: true
    highlight-style: github
    prefer-html: true
    reference-doc: oaph-reference-doc.docx
mainfont: "Georgia"
bibliography: references.bib
csl: APA Numeric Superscript Style.csl
engine: knitr
---

title: 5  Word
text:
5.2 Create Your Own
In the Document Templates folder:

Download the file oaph-reference-doc.docx
Download the file word-template.qmd (to the same location/folder on your computer as the file above) and follow the instructions.

title: 6  Presentation Slides
text:
6.1 Example YAML Statement
---
title: "Title of Document"
subtitle: "Subtitle of Document"
author: "Ohio Alliance for Population Health <br> Your Name"
format: 
  revealjs:
    logo: 'oaph-logo.png'
    footer: '[www.ohio.edu/chsp/alliance](https://www.ohio.edu/chsp/alliance)'
    css: oaph-theme.css
bibliography: "references.bib"
csl: "APA Numeric Superscript Style.csl"
---

title: 6  Presentation Slides
text:
6.2 Create Your Own
In the Document Templates folder:

Download the file oaph-reference-doc.docx
Download the file slide-presentation-template.qmd (to the same location/folder on your computer as the file above) and follow the instructions.

Add link to beamer presentations

title: 7  Title of Document
text:
8 Slide 1 Title
Hello! This is an example of a slide presentation. Write your text here.

More information on the examples provided in these slides
More advanced examples of what you can include in your slides
Key point

Add an Image:



9 Slide 2 - Columns
Add a hyperlink HERE


Column 1

Bold Text


Column 2

Italicized Text





10 Zotero Citations
Use {.smaller .scrollable} after slide/section title if text is too big or runs off slide
Add a Zotero citation here1.

Add citation to Zotero library (manually or using browser extension).
Copy citation key from info tab in Zotero and paste where you want citation located in document example: @examplecitationkey2024.
Right click name of collection on left side of Zotero window and select “Export Collection…”
Select Better BibTeX from dropdown menu (no selection under translator options) then click OK.
Rename to references.bib and save file to the same folder your .qmd (Quarto) document is in.
Go to the Common Citation Styles folder.

If the required citation style for your document is listed download the .csl file and move into the same folder your .qmd (Quarto) document is in. Skip steps 7-10.
If your required citation style is not listed in this folder follow steps 7-10 below.

Go to Zotero Citation Repository and find the citation style required for your document (can use search bar).
Click the name of the citation style in blue text.
When asked “Add citation style to Zotero?” click cancel/no. This should cause a .csl file to download.
Move this .csl file to the same folder your .qmd (Quarto) document is in.
In your YAML statement at the top of the page change csl: to the name of the citation style .csl file. Example csl: APA Numeric Superscript Style.csl
Click the “Render” button at the top of your R editor panel (below file name tab).
